cmCourseInfo.description: This highly interactive course for English Language Learners who find Academic English a challenge aims to fast-track the development of critical thinking, reading, writing and oral communication skills. Through emphasizing academic writing and rapid expansion of vocabulary, students will gain practical experience with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations in Effective Academic Communication
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No more than 10.0 credits completed. Students are required to take a diagnostic test of academic English skills to be conducted by the English Language Development Support,  Centre for Teaching and Learning, in advance of the first day of class.
cmCourseInfo.note: The instructor has the authority to exclude students whose level of proficiency is unsuitable for the course, including those students who meet the prerequisites.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Period 1: Initially restricted to first and second year students with no more than 10 credits.
Period 2: On Thursday, July 27th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining spaces may open to other UTSC students.

Students must enroll into Practicum 0001 or 0002 scheduled on Wednesdays, 12pm-1pm. Practicums start in Week 2. Students are also recommended to take the diagnostic test Academic English Health Check (AEHC) conducted by English Language Development Support in advance of the first day of class. Link to schedule and sign-up: https://uoft.me/aehc

cmCourseInfo.description: This highly interactive course for English Language Learners who find Academic English a challenge aims to fast-track the development of critical thinking, reading, writing and oral communication skills. Through emphasizing academic writing and rapid expansion of vocabulary, students will gain practical experience with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations in Effective Academic Communication
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No more than 10.0 credits completed. Students are required to take a diagnostic test of academic English skills to be conducted by the English Language Development Support,  Centre for Teaching and Learning, in advance of the first day of class.
cmCourseInfo.note: The instructor has the authority to exclude students whose level of proficiency is unsuitable for the course, including those students who meet the prerequisites.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Period 1: Initially restricted to first and second year students with no more than 10 credits.
Period 2: On Thursday, July 27th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining spaces may open to other UTSC students.

All students must enroll in Practicum 001 scheduled on Wednesdays 12pm - 1pm. Practicums start in Week 2. Students are also recommended to take the diagnostic test Academic English Health Check (AEHC) conducted by English Language Development Support in advance of the first day of class. Link to schedule and sign-up: https://uoft.me/aehc

courses.name: Writing for Change: Foundational Academic Skills to Make a Difference in Your Community

cmCourseInfo.description: This course uses the mode of advocacy writing to teach the foundational skills necessary for all effective communication. Students will learn to convey their ideas about issues relevant to their communities with attention to structure, voice, evidence, and writing mechanics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing for Change: Foundational Academic Skills to Make a Difference in Your Community
cmCourseInfo.note: This course is available to students in the Transitional Year Program only, and students will be enrolled into the course by program administrators.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RE
This course is restricted to students enrolled in the UTSC Transitional Year Program (TYP).

For more information regarding the Transitional Year Program at UTSC, please visit: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/typ-utsc/

courses.name: Math4life: Developing Mathematical Thinking and Skills in Practical Contexts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will cover basic mathematics concepts such as Arithmetic, Elementary Algebra, Geometry and Trigonometry, Data collection and Interpretation, Sets, and Functions. Students will engage these concepts through a series of activities which require them to solve practical problems based on real life circumstances. The course will also draw on African and Indigenous cultural knowledges and perspectives to connect the study of mathematics to TYP students’ interests and lived experiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Math4life: Developing Mathematical Thinking and Skills in Practical Contexts
cmCourseInfo.note: This course is available to students in the Transitional Year Program only, and students will be enrolled in the course by program administrators.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RE
This course is restricted to students enrolled in the UTSC Transitional Year Program (TYP).

For more information regarding the Transitional Year Program at UTSC, please visit: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/typ-utsc/

cmCourseInfo.description: In this experiential learning course, students apply their discipline-specific academic knowledge as they learn from and engage with communities. Students provide, and gain, unique perspectives and insights as they interact with community partners. Through class discussions, workshops and assignments, students also develop transferable life skills such as interpersonal communication, professionalism and self-reflection that support their learning experiences and help them connect theory and practice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Community Engaged Learning
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 4.0 credits and selection of a U of T Scarborough Specialist or Major program. GPA will also be considered.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: A
Step 1: Request the course in ACORN (you will receive an INT status, but will not be officially enrolled in the course) or join the Waitlist.
NOTE: Do not let the waitlist status discourage you from applying for a placement. (see Step 3)
Step 2: For full details of the course and the list of Community Placement Opportunities and How to Apply, go to https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/ctl/experiential-learning
Step 3: Wait for your application to be accepted by the community organization. Once your application has been accepted, we will officially enroll you into the course [APP status], regardless of Waitlist status.

For detailed information regarding CTLB03, please visit our webpage: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/ctl/experiential-learning
Mandatory attendance for weekly in-person lectures.
